utterances: So that's the bitter, what's the sweet?
The sweet is that, you know, with every door that closes, there is always a new door that opens.
And we have always been have had the long-term interest of the university in mind.
And we are continuing our process of trying to help them figure out can this tradition move on in some ways, shape or form, even though, it has to close on Wednesday.
Now, I understand the e-mails are already flying among alumni.
What's the likely reaction?
There are passionate sides and there are alumni who I can say are the silent majority and who take great pride and excitement over this.
I think in the short term, there will be a lot of emotion to it.
Hopefully, over time, we can find something that allow the tradition to continue, and possibly, hopefully to satisfy that excitement that that happens at halftime of football and basketball game.
You know, we've talked about this as it served as a somber day for you.
But there are a lot of people who are actually very happy about this.
This is a victory for some who thought that the chief was offensive.
I am Mohammed Ismail Yusanto, the spokesperson of Hizbut Tahrir Indonesia.
I got up into the breeze, not on purpose.
We do, actually.

We get a various range of visitors - families that come down here and make this kind of an annual track because we do decorate all the houses at Christmastime - with various greeneries, wreaths done of natural things like of shells, fruits and such.

So people come down here to look at the Christmastide decorations, have meals in one of our taverns as well as come to see some of the historic buildings and get back to their history and see how life was celebrated in the 18th century.
Does the workday for you feel very different from every other workday at Williamsburg?
It's a little bit different.
We don't have to work as many hours today.
The museum is not open a full day.
And we do revolutionary city, where you talk politics a lot and such like this.
And today, we just basically talk about Christmastide parties and enjoy our singing and such like that.
So it's a looser day for us.
No politics on Christmas, huh?
No politics on Christmas.
All right.
Well, Lee Ann, thanks a lot for your time.
Have a wonderful Christmas.
And you have a very happy Christmas yourself.
Thank you.
Thank you.
Lee Ann Holfelder is a historic interpreter of Colonial Williamsburg.
She joined us from her office in Williamsburg, Virginia.
And we have an e-mail here from Robin(ph) in Ann Harbor.
She writes: I'm a professional pet sitter.
And as someone who used to travel a lot, I know how important it is to feel like you're leaving your pets and your home in good hands.
She writes, I'm happily having a very busy holiday week, caring for other people's dogs, cats and guinea pigs.
Well, our next guest is Sergeant Kale Murray.
He is working Christmas Day at Missile Command Center at Schriever Air Force Base in Colorado Springs, Colorado.
He is a future operations officer.
And Sergeant Murray, what is exactly does that mean?
Well, good afternoon and merry Christmas.
Good afternoon and merry Christmas to you, too.
Thank you.
But what we do is - my job, I'm on the missile defense crew, obviously.
We operate the ballistic missile defense shield that was built in a few years ago.

What I do is I'm an analyst, and I basically look out there at the real-world intelligence situations going on the world, and we make battle assessments and so forth and just trying to figure out what's going on out there and things that we need to be aware of to help protect the nation.
So I guess everybody listening would hope that you have a very quiet Christmas.
Oh, yes.
Absolutely.
And just so everyone knows, it's been a very quiet Christmas so far today.
Have you ever experienced any close calls?
No.
We do lots of training, obviously.
You know, nearly every day we're at work, we do some sort of training.
But, no, nothing like that.
The system is in place to protect against a road launch or, you know, possibly an (unintelligible) launch anywhere around the world.
But nothing that I have ever seen has come close to being a crisis situation.
What happens if you do see something on the radar?
Well, if we do see something, then we have a series of steps in place, obviously, all the way up to the commander in chief, things that would have to be (unintelligible).

One of my jobs is now also to figure out, you know, is this serious or is it not, and then pass on that information on up to chain of command and someone, you know, (unintelligible) would make a decision on how to deal with that.
You know, I have to ask, do you have any specialized technology that lets you distinguish between a missile and, say, Santa Claus?
Well, actually, yes.
You may be very well familiar with the NORAD Tracks Santa program that they do every year.
In fact, I spoke with my commander this morning.
He was working there last night - taking phone calls from kids around the world.
And we can definitely tell the difference between a missile and Santa Claus.
(Soundbite of laughter)
It's a big relief.
Well, do you have any special traditions at the office for Christmastime?
Well, what we normally do is we try to let as many people off work as possible.
We get business from our commanders and phone calls and so forth.
And we usually bring in some kind of a holiday bread or, you know, snacks and just try to be cheery and have a great Christmas.
And does that mean that you don't get to celebrate with your family?
Well, actually, we do.
In my case, my family - we opened most of our presents last night.
And then my children who like to pick it out with me at 3:45 this morning and see what Santa Claus had brought.
And so we actually had a very early Christmas.
And I came on into work and I'm sure they were back to bed.
Sounds great.
All right.
Well, Sergeant Murray, thanks a lot for joining us.
Thank you so much and have a great day.
You, too.
All right.
Sergeant Kale Murray is a future operations officer for Missile Defense.
And he joined us from his office at Schriever Air Force Base in Colorado Springs.
Let's go to a caller.
This is Christine(ph) in Shorewood.
Hi, Christine.
Hello.
Good afternoon.
Merry Christmas.
It is snowing.

I was here today and I just noticed how nice the roads are because the public works crew has been out and about on Christmas Day, clearing the roads so we can get to-and-fro safely and people can enjoy a beautiful winter day.
Anybody else in particular that stands out in your mind in your town who is sort of the unsung hero of Christmas, letting people do what they would otherwise do this day?
Yeah.
I know that, you know, that we also have police and fire.
And driving past the department buildings, I see cars out there and trucks and, you know, as always, the emergency responders who are ready to drop anything and go to where they're needed.
And it's pretty sleepy and quiet out here today.
It's kind of a heat wave of 28 degrees.
So I think our people will be out and about.
But I just - I know that, you know, cities keep running because there are good staff people and people who want to make it easy for the rest of us.
All right, Christine, thanks a lot for your call.
Hey, thank you.
Have a great day.
You too.
Bye.
Bye.
